summary: Temperatures across the country have dropped significantly in the wake of a cold front, with temperatures nearly 20 degrees colder than the previous day. Temperatures will continue to fall through the early hours of New Year's Eve, with western Kansas expected to see temperatures in the teens for western Kansas and in the 20s for central Kansas. Southerly winds will help western Kansas climb into the mid to upper 40s by the afternoon, while central Kansas will sit in the low 40s and upper 30s. The region will remain seasonal for the first week of January, with highs expected to sit in mid-40s. Potential moisture could shift across the Sunflower State on Friday, potentially leading to rainfall and transition to snowfall.

title: Ringing in 2024: New Year’s Eve Celebrations with Heightened Security and Stunning Fireworks Around the World
description: Ringing in 2024: New Year’s Eve Celebrations with Heightened Security and Stunning Fireworks Around the World
content:
Ringing in 2024: New Year’s Eve photos from around the world

In New York City, the NYPD has heightened security for the famed Times Square ball drop following Hamas’ attack on Israel, CBS New York reported. Despite added safety measures, the FBI said there is no credible threat to New York City, As covered by CBS New York.

Throughout the world, people are gathering to mark the arrival of 2024 with grand firework displays and festivities. From Sydney and Auckland to Dubai and Hong Kong, cities are lighting up the sky to welcome the new year. Despite the celebrations, security measures have been increased in some locations following recent events.
summary: The world is celebrating the arrival of 2024 with New Year's Eve celebrations, with celebrations across the world, including in New York City, Australia, and Dubai, and Hong Kong. Despite increased security measures in some locations due to Hamas' attack on Israel, the NYPD has increased security for the Times Square ball drop. The FBI has stated that there is no credible threat to New York. Despite heightened security measures, the FBI has ruled out any threat to the city.

title: Addressing Physician Burnout: Strategies for Redesigning Medical Practices
description: Learn about the impact of physician burnout and how to promote well-being in the medical profession. Explore strategies and resources to address stress and improve patient care.
content:
Physician burnout is a critical issue that affects the well-being of healthcare professionals. It is characterized by emotional exhaustion, depersonalization, and a diminished sense of personal accomplishment, often as a result of prolonged work stress. This burnout not only affects the physicians themselves but can also have a detrimental effect on patient care and physician satisfaction. The medical profession, with its long hours and intense demands, is particularly susceptible to this condition.

One of the key strategies to address physician burnout is to redesign medical practices in a way that reduces stress and promotes well-being. This involves creating a healthier work environment where physicians can thrive without compromising their mental or physical health. This could include introducing more flexible work schedules, providing better support systems, and encouraging a more balanced lifestyle.

Several resources are available to help physicians make these changes. The American Medical Association (AMA), for instance, offers a variety of content related to physician burnout, including podcasts and articles discussing the issue, as well as resources and tips for prevention and mitigation of burnout. Information on AMA advocacy efforts and events, as well as membership benefits and discounts, can also be found on their website.

Another valuable resource for physicians is the Continuing Medical Education (CME) course on physician burnout. This course aims to provide practical strategies for managing stress and promoting well-being in the medical profession. It includes various studies, viewpoints, and essays discussing burnout, professional well-being, and strategies to improve the well-being of physicians and medical students.

One such CME event is ‘Awake and Aware 2024’, which focuses on overcoming burnout and improving mindset. Another course is the ‘Flameproof Course’, which aims to make participants burnout resistant. Both these courses offer strategies to overcome resistance and provide guidance on handling critical patients without prior notice.

The Impact of COVID-19 on Physician Burnout

The COVID-19 pandemic has further exacerbated the issue of physician burnout. The increased workload, the fear of infection, and the emotional toll of treating critically ill patients have all contributed to higher levels of stress among healthcare professionals. It is therefore more important than ever to address physician burnout and promote well-being within the medical profession.

In conclusion, addressing physician burnout is a critical step towards enhancing the well-being of healthcare professionals and improving patient care. Redesigning medical practices, providing resources for support, and offering CME courses on physician burnout can all help to create a healthier work environment for physicians. By investing in the mental health of our medical professionals, we can ensure better healthcare for all.
summary: Physician burnout, characterized by emotional exhaustion, depersonalization, and a diminished sense of personal accomplishment due to prolonged work stress. This condition can also negatively impact patient care and physician satisfaction. One of the key strategies to address physician burnout is to redesign medical practices in a way that reduces stress and promotes well-being. This includes creating a healthier work environment where physicians thrive without compromising their mental or physical health. Resources such as the American Medical Association (AMA) are available to help physicians make these changes. The Continuing Medical Education (CME) course on doctor burnout aims to provide practical strategies for managing stress and promoting health in the medical profession. The impact of the COVID-19 pandemic has exacerbated the issue, contributing to increased workload, fear of infection, and emotional toll of treating critically ill patients.

title: The Power of Medical Drones: Transforming Healthcare Delivery
description: - ISP Today
content:
In today’s fast-paced world, technological advancements continue to shape various industries, and healthcare is no exception. Among the game-changing technologies that are emerging, drones are proving to be potential game-changers in the healthcare sector. With their ability to deliver medication, defibrillators, and emergency first aid supplies, drones offer a faster and more efficient approach to emergency medical services (EMS), ultimately saving lives and revolutionizing medical delivery.

Recent success stories highlight the immense potential of drones in healthcare. In a groundbreaking partnership between Japanese and Mongolian UAV and healthcare organizations, a blood delivery operation was successfully conducted using an AirTruck logistics drone. Overcoming challenging weather conditions, this mission demonstrated the resilience and possibilities of drone technology for medical deliveries.

Another remarkable achievement took place in the Ethiopian Highlands, where Australian firm Swoop Aero employed drone technology to deliver over 6000 vaccine doses to remote areas. This exemplifies the profound impact of drone delivery systems on healthcare in hard-to-reach regions.

While the integration of drones in healthcare delivery presents promising opportunities, it also poses challenges and regulatory considerations. Concerns around safety, privacy, and necessary infrastructure must be addressed. Nevertheless, companies are actively working to overcome these hurdles and harness the immense benefits of drone technology.

Amid financial challenges, Spright, a medical drone delivery company affiliated with Air Methods, is expanding its drone fleet for emergency medical services. They have achieved significant milestones, including obtaining FAA waivers for specific missions and completing the longest BVLOS drone flight by a commercial entity in the US. Additionally, Spright is deploying drone delivery mailboxes and collaborating with Interpath Laboratory to create a drone delivery network for lab sample transportation in Oregon.

Japan is also at the forefront of drone-assisted healthcare delivery. ACSL, a Japanese drone manufacturer, recently completed its third Level 4 drone delivery of medical supplies in Tokyo. This achievement demonstrates their commitment to developing safe and secure drones, with the aim of transforming society and promoting the widespread use of drones.

In conclusion, the integration of drones in medical delivery is an exciting development that has the potential to revolutionize healthcare and emergency response systems. As drone technology continues to advance, we are only beginning to scratch the surface of its profound impact, especially in rural and inaccessible areas. While challenges and regulations must be addressed, the future of medical delivery through drones looks incredibly promising.

1. How can drones be used in healthcare?

 Drones can be used in healthcare to deliver medication, defibrillators, and emergency first aid supplies, particularly in hard-to-reach and remote areas.

2. What success stories highlight the potential of drones in healthcare?

 One success story involves a blood delivery operation conducted using a logistics drone in Japan and Mongolia. Another achievement includes the delivery of over 6000 vaccine doses to remote areas in the Ethiopian Highlands.

3. What challenges does the integration of drones in healthcare present?

 The integration of drones in healthcare delivery poses challenges such as safety concerns, privacy issues, and the need for necessary infrastructure.

4. How are companies addressing the challenges of drone technology in healthcare?

 Companies like Spright are actively working to overcome challenges by expanding their drone fleet, obtaining necessary waivers, and collaborating with other organizations to create a drone delivery network for medical services.

5. What achievements has ACSL, a Japanese drone manufacturer, made in healthcare delivery?

 ACSL has recently completed its third Level 4 drone delivery of medical supplies in Tokyo, showcasing their commitment to developing safe and secure drones for healthcare.

1. UAV – Unmanned Aerial Vehicle, commonly known as a drone.

 2. EMS – Emergency Medical Services, referring to the medical response provided in emergencies.

 3. BVLOS – Beyond Visual Line of Sight, indicating drone flights that go beyond the pilot’s line of sight.

1. Air Methods – Air Methods is the parent company of Spright, a medical drone delivery company mentioned in the article.

 2. Swoop Aero – Swoop Aero is the Australian firm mentioned in the article that employed drone technology for vaccine delivery in remote areas.

 3. ACSL – ACSL is the Japanese drone manufacturer mentioned in the article that completed drone deliveries of medical supplies in Tokyo.
summary: The article discusses the potential of drones to revolutionize healthcare and emergency response systems. Drones are proving to be game-changers in the healthcare sector, delivering medication, defibrillators, and emergency first aid supplies. Successful success stories include a blood delivery operation conducted using a logistics drone in Japan and Mongolia, and the delivery of over 6000 vaccine doses to remote areas in the Ethiopian Highlands. However, challenges and regulatory considerations regarding safety, privacy, and necessary infrastructure must be addressed. Companies like Spright are working to overcome these challenges by expanding their drone fleet and collaborating with other organizations to create a drone delivery network for medical services. Japanese drone manufacturer ACSL recently completed its third Level 4 drone delivery of medical supplies in Tokyo.

title: New in 2024: Marines train more drone pilots, fill MQ-9 squadrons
description: Three locations use the Reaper drone — and the Corps plans to open a support unit in Cherry Point, North Carolina.
content:
The Marine Corps has so far trained 100 leathernecks as MQ-9 pilots as it seeks to fill out new squadrons with the uncrewed system to extend reach and reconnaissance for its own drone program.

The Corps first leased the MQ-9 Reaper in 2018 and only received funding to purchase the drones in 2020, the same year the service created the Reaper military occupational specialty of 7318.

In the 2022 aviation plan, the Corps noted it had trained only 38 of the then-68 pilots it needed, which continue to be commissioned officers, despite the Air Force’s use of warrant officer drone pilots.

The Reaper first fielded to the U.S. Air Force in 2007 and was used extensively throughout the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, and operations globally. The Air Force operated more than 300 Reapers as of 2021, Defense News previously reported.

Marine Corps now has unit in Indo-Pacific flying Reaper drones

The Reaper is the Corps’ first group five drone. The service has long operated group three drones, such as the RQ-21A Blackjack.

A group three drone weighs between 55 pounds and 1,320 pounds, typically operating below 18,000 feet. The group five drones weigh more than 1,320 pounds and operate at altitudes higher than 18,000 feet.

Three units currently operate the Reaper: VMU-1 in Yuma, Arizona; UX-24 at Naval Air Station Patuxent River, Maryland; and VMU-3 at Marine Corps Air Station Kaneohe Bay, Hawaii.

VMU-1 was the first operational squadron to use the Reaper, conducting intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance support in U.S. Central Command beginning in 2018.

UX-24 is an aviation testing unit. And VMU-3 reached initial operational capability in August, Marine Corps Times previously reported.

The VMU-3 “Phantoms” provide aerial reconnaissance for the 3rd Marine Littoral Regiment.

Marine spokesman Maj. Jordan Fox said in March that the squadron supports “a wide range of operations such as coastal and border surveillance, weapons tracking, embargo enforcement, humanitarian/disaster assistance, support of peacekeeping and counter-narcotic operations.”

Marines plan to establish the MQ-9A Fleet Replacement Squadron in Cherry Point, North Carolina, Capt. Alyssa Myers told Marine Corps Times.

Former Commandant Gen. David Berger in January 2023 posed a question to Marine aviation leaders in the services’s training and education planning document whether the service should consider options other than commissioned officers to fly the Reaper, given a shortage of fixed wing pilots.

To date, the Corps has stuck with commissioned officers for those jobs.

Under current plans, the Corps aims to field 20 reaper drones over the next decade, Myers said.

keywords.name: Marine Corps Air Station Kaneohe Bay

summary: The Marine Corps has trained 100 leathernecks as MQ-9 pilots to fill out new squadrons with the uncrewed system to extend reach and reconnaissance for its own drone program. The Corps first leased the Mq-9 Reaper in 2018 and only received funding to purchase the drones in 2020, the same year the service created the Reaper military occupational specialty of 7318. The Reaper was first fielded to the U.S. Air Force in 2007 and was used extensively throughout the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan and operations globally. Three units currently operate the Reaper, VMU-1 in Yuma, Arizona, UX-24 at Naval Air Station Patuxent River, Maryland, and VMUU-3 at Marine Corps Air Station Kaneohe Bay, Hawaii. The Marines plan to establish the MQue-9A Fleet Replacement Squadron in Cherry Point, North Carolina, and aim to field 20 Reapers over the next decade.

title: Panthers owner David Tepper tosses drink into visiting stands late in 26-0 loss to Jaguars
description: Panthers owner David Tepper threw the contents of a drink into the visiting crowd near the end of Carolina’s 26-0 loss at Jacksonville
content:
Carolina Panthers offensive tackle Taylor Moton greets quarterback Bryce Young during their loss against the Jacksonville Jaguars in an NFL football game Sunday, Dec. 31, 2023, in Jacksonville, Fla. (AP Photo/Phelan M. Ebenhack)

Panthers owner David Tepper threw the contents of a drink into the visiting crowd near the end of Carolina’s 26-0 loss at Jacksonville on Sunday.

Tepper’s reaction came after rookie Bryce Young was intercepted with less than 3 minutes to play. It was unclear whether Tepper was reacting to something said to him or the latest miscue for the team with the NFL’s worst record.

General manager Scott Fitterer was standing near Tepper when he tossed the remnants of his drink while watching the game from a club suite.

The Panthers (2-14) dropped to 0-9 on the road and were shut out for the first time since losing to Atlanta in Week 12 in 2002. They also clinched the No. 1 overall pick in the NFL draft in April — a selection that will go to Chicago.

Nothing went right in this one for Carolina, and had Jacksonville not gone 1 for 5 scoring in the red zone, the outcome likely would have been way more lopsided.

Bryce Young completed 19 of 32 passes for 112 yards, with an interception, and was sacked six times. He now has been sacked a whopping 59 times.

“Yeah, not fun. Not fun at all,” Young said. “It’s on us. It’s what we put out. It’s our tape. It’s what we did. We own it, accept it. It is what it is, but it’s not fun.”

Carolina had issues before the coin flip.

Kicker Eddy Pineiro injured his right hamstring in pregame warmups and was unable to go. Starting linebacker Kamu Grugier-Hill handled the opening kickoff, and interim coach Chris Tabor kept his offense on the field for a fourth-and-7 play in normal field-goal range on the team’s opening drive.

Young was sacked and took a shot to his back. He spent several minutes getting checked on the sideline and returned in time for the next series.

“Obviously when there’s only one kicker on your 48, that’s a tough deal,” Tabor said.

Cornerback Jaycee Horn (toe) also was a late scratch after going through warmups. Horn had been scheduled to play, and Tabor even made CJ Henderson inactive. But Horn couldn’t go, so Shaquill Griffin was thrust into the starting lineup.

Griffin was burned for a 48-yard gain, part of a lackluster performance all around for the visitors.

“I’m disappointed, obviously, and that’s a pretty generic answer,” Tabor said. “Did not see it coming. I will tip my hat to the Jaguars. The way we were trending, I did not see this performance coming down.

“We never got on track. We talked a lot about starting fast this week, and we did not do that. ... How are you going to deal with it? There’s only two choices: It’s either character or compromise. Those are questions for everybody.”

The Panthers had more injury issues during the game. Guard Cade Mays left with a finger injury and then linebacker Marquis Haynes, a sixth-year pro who grew up in Jacksonville, was carted off the field in the third quarter with a concussion. He was taken to a hospital for further testing and did not fly home with the team.

Haynes flashed a thumbs-up sign to the crowd as he left the stadium. It was one of the few occasions Carolina fans had to cheer.

The Panthers finished with 124 yards, were 1 of 13 on third down and had defensive lineman Derrick Brown ejected along with Jacksonville left tackle Cam Robinson late in the fourth. They ripped off each other’s helmets after a play.

“Missed opportunities. Just execution top to bottom,” Young said. “There’s a long list of stuff I’ve got to do better, and then offensively we all take responsibility. We all look in the mirror, and I think ‘disconnected’ is a good word.

“Just wasn’t executing, wasn’t translating, and as far as the offense, that’s on me.”
summary: Carolina Panthers lost 26-0 to Jacksonville Jaguars in an NFL football game, marking their first road loss since 2002. Panthers owner David Tepper threw a drink into the visiting crowd late in the game, following rookie Bryce Young's interception. The team's poor performance left them with the NFL's worst record and clinching the No. 1 overall pick in the NFL draft in April. Key players included kicker Eddy Pineiro, defensive lineman Cam Robinson, and defensive lineman Derrick Brown. The Jaguars also had a poor performance, finishing with only 124 yards, and were 1 of 13 on third down.

title: BREAKING: RCCG's Adeboye Releases 2024 Prophecies
description: The General Overseer of the Redeemed Christian Church of God (RCCG), Pastor Enoch Adeboye, has released 2024 prophecies. Naija News reports that the
content:
The General Overseer of the Redeemed Christian Church of God (RCCG), Pastor Enoch Adeboye, has released 2024 prophecies.

Naija News reports that the internationally renowned cleric released the prophecies during the RCCG Cross Over service held at the Redemption City in Ogun State.

1. The wind is blowing (ask God to allow the wind to blow you good).

2. Things will get worse before it gets better in 2024.

3. Because the wind is blowing, some serious secrets would come into the open.

4. There are some people who would start the year as nothing (nobody) but become significant before the end of the year.

5. There will be many opportunities this year, so get ready to grab them.

There will be divine intervention in those places that are hot.

There would be quite medical breakthroughs in areas like cancer, asthma, hypertension, and sugar diabetes.

summary: Pastor Enoch Adeboye, the General Overseer of the Redeemed Christian Church of God (RCCG), has released 2024 prophecies. The prophecies were made during the RCCG Cross Over service at the Redemption City in Ogun State. They warn that things will change before they improve in 2024, with some people starting the year as nothing but significant before the end of the year. They also predict that there will be medical breakthroughs in areas like cancer, asthma, hypertension, and sugar diabetes.

title: The government will work to boost the economy and fight crime head on news
description: The President of the Republic, Tina Poluarte, said that in 2024 the government will act decisively to boost the economy and fight crime, because these are
content:
The President of the Republic, Tina Poluarte, said that in 2024 the government will act decisively to boost the economy and fight crime, because these are the most important issues for all citizens.

Ahead of the New Year 2024, he said in a message that the arrival of 2024 will open a new chapter in the country's history and hence the executive branch will focus on bridging gaps and improving health services, education, water etc. and health and social inclusion.

“This year, we will focus all our efforts on the two highest priorities: boosting the economy and leading the fight against crime and crime.“, emphasized the President.
summary: The President of the Republic, Tina Poluarte, has stated that in 2024, the government will act decisively to boost the economy and fight crime, as these are the most important issues for citizens. The executive branch will focus on improving health services, education, water, and health and social inclusion. Poluarté emphasized the importance of these efforts in preparing for the New Year 2024, stating that this will open a new chapter in the country's history.

title: 2023 Year in Review: Another year where the potential for cycling is undermined by slow progress and poor quality routes -- IrishCycle
description: 2023 broke records in terms of extreme heat linked to climate change in Europe, and, in Ireland, the EPA warned that targeted emission reduction will fall short, with transport as one of the worst …
content:
2023 broke records in terms of extreme heat linked to climate change in Europe, and, in Ireland, the EPA warned that targeted emission reduction will fall short, with transport as one of the worst sectors. Cycling is nowhere near to playing its part in emission reductions — the speed and quality of the roll-out of route just isn’t up to the job.

Transport Minister Eamon Ryan had called on councils to progress Pathfinder Projects which show the way forward. But, so far, these projects are proving to be delayed or of low quality or far lower impact than you would expect.

Red C research commissioned by the Department of Transport found that 60% of respondents are willing to change their transport choices to reduce carbon emissions but campaigners questioned the availability of alternatives to allow people to change.

At the start of the year, IrishCycle.com reported that quick-build cycle routes to Ranelagh and Ballsbridge were expected to be rolled out in 2023 but have still not been built. The route to Ballsbrisge has also been cut into two halves.

This website also reported on a Pathfinder plan to rapidly reallocate Dublin City Centre space to boost walking, cycling, and buses. This too is behind its original time frame and as reported in January, it likely was delayed already at that stage — a central backing for the changes, the City Centre Transport Study was to be made public in Q1 2023 but it was flagged a number of times including in June and it was then eventually only published in September.

After that, this website also covered what is included in the plan and then also focused on the cycling elements of the draft city centre plan.

Planning also continued for Dublin’s MetroLink project — at the start of the year, campaigners highlighted that stations are to have bicycle parking for just 28% of the predicted demand. Last month, in their official response to issues, the MetroLink project team said that they’d told An Bord Pleanála that bicycles on board isn’t a planning issue.

In February, IrishCycle.com reported how Minister Eamon Ryan confirmed details of €290m walking and cycling funding for 2023. While in October this website was able to report how Active Travel spending by Irish councils hit €310m in 2022, up from an initial budget of €289m.

Officials in Dublin said this year that there is not enough funding for crossings or traffic calming, but, very strangely, the 2022 funding included using €27 million of ‘Active Travel’ funding for enabling works on Waterford’s car-focused North Quays. While the council claimed that this was for the bridge which would form part of a walking and cycling route, after quite a lot of work on this story, the NTA confirmed that the funding was for general enabling workings for the site.

The Waterford Quays project is also billed as a Pathfinder project but it’s unclear how when the non-waterfront part of the development is bordered by a four-lane road which is being expanded as part of the project.

There was some progress in Cork on the reallocation of space to cycling but, as covered, Cork City Council is kind of fudging design work at junctions. The multi-million euro revamp of Cork’s MacCurtain St is still being treated as a car park.

Also back in February, in the case of the Strand Road cycle route trial planned for Sandymount, the Court of Appeal Justices outlined how there was a “critical issue” that the then High Court Judge disregarded evidence that the cycleway would be temporary. We’re still awaiting a written judgment in the case.

In the meantime, Irish Water ended up closing Strand Road in the northbound direction, but despite the closure northbound, Southsiders still found Dublin Airport. Traffic counts later showed increases, decreases and balancing of traffic in the area.

Another issue the Court of Appeal Justices complained about was the lack of Government guidelines covering Section 38 of the Road Traffic Acts. This was fixed in October when new guidelines clarified Irish councils’ powers to install cycling and bus priority measures permanently or as a trial under Section 38. There was a bit of disbelief about the guidelines but it turns out the guidelines said exactly what IrishCycle.com had reported.

These are national guidelines covering Section 38 of the Road Traffic Act 1994, which was last amended by Section 46 of the Public Transportation Regulation Act 2009. So, the law, approved by the Dail, hasn’t changed in 14 years but some Dublin councillors complained strongly. At least Cllr Mannix Flynn is nothing if not consistent — he has been complaining about Section 38 since 2016.

This denial that the law says what it does has now been the subject of hours of council meetings, a High Court Case, a Court of Appeal case… and it’s maybe going to rumble on legally or in political rhetoric terms for a while longer.

There was also a lot of denial of the price tag of €30.8 million for a 2.1km section of the Royal Canal Greenway. In March, this website covered some of the complexity which explains the price. That includes a large amount which was set aside for contingency and risk, but it’s also because the project is not just expanding paths but includes bridges, complicated structures and crossings of three busy main roads.

A bit of a sting is left by the fact due to concerns about the loss of trees and the constraints of the canal, the final product was narrowed and will include sections of 1.5 metres for footpaths and 2.5 metres two-way cycle paths, which is inadequate for this kind of urban area.

On the other side of the country, Limerick’s South Circular Road project gained approval from councillors. After a long drawn-out battle, a plan was hatched so that automated bollards would allow for car parking and two-way cycling on a shared surface on a contentious part of the route.

IrishCycle.com covered how the Liffey Valley BusConnects project should be a wake-up call for better design for walking and cycling — that project included trialling bicycle lights at the back of bus stops. The first full implementation of a scaled-down version of traffic lights at bus stops is due to happen on the Clontarf to City Centre plan, a plan for which includes two traffic lights at most of the 12 bus stops along the route.

Most of the inbound section of the Clontarf route is now open, with fitting for the traffic lights to be installed later.

The quality of walking and cycling projects was again a recurring theme in 2023 — for example, South Dublin County Council’s Grange Road walking and cycling project had some constraints to deal with but there’s no excuse for most issues. Choices are being made at the design stage of projects that don’t add up.

The lack of progress the quality of projects prompted IrishCycle.com to pen a letter to Minister Ryan covering how no one expects micro-managing, but how he is are responsible for how €1m per day on walking and cycling is spent.

Census 2022 data released in May showed that nearly 100k people commute by bicycle daily in Ireland, with a large jump in children cycling.

IrishCycle.com’s most read article — by a long shot — was also published in May: News of Fingal County Council opening Ireland’s first Dutch-style roundabout in Dublin 15. Another Dutch-style walking and cycling priority roundabout is now proposed in Dublin 16 by South Dublin County Council.

Also in May, the car-free Capel Street was marked as a success after its first year. While, at the other end of the scale, the launching of mostly sign-posted only Irish EuroVelo 1 route still leaves people cycling using busy 100km/h national roads for sections of the route.

In June, IrishCycle.com covered how city councils were still struggling to hire staff for rollout of walking and cycling routes.

Plans for making Dún Laoghaire’s Coastal Mobility Route permanent were released in July. 75% of public consultation respondents supported making it permanent. While the council also opened an extension of the route to the Dublin City boundary.

A pro-high car use meeting in Dundrum ended with a Gestapo jibe left unchallenged by the meeting’s organisers. Later in the year, there was also trouble at a council meeting covering the Living Streets Dún Laoghaire project and a councillor walked out of the meeting after refusing to withdraw a “propaganda” comment because of his annoyance at a video produced for the council.

In August, IrishCycle.com started a series giving you an insight into the views and backgrounds of some of Ireland’s cycling campaigners — you can read back on those articles here.

The long-awaited Cycle Design Manual, which replaces the National Cycle Manual, was published in September after the councils had given it around a month before. But low-quality designs are still being planned by councils.

One example is another Pathfinder project — the Beaver Row and Beech Hill Road project which this website said is not fit to be a Pathfinder project to the extent that it should be defunded. Another, is a new 200m cycle path in Dún Laoghaire which will have shared footpath-like surfaces at both ends.

Minister Ryan did however remove a project from the Pathfinder programme after it was found that it would not be finished in time. But the Minister has yet to pay as much attention to the quality of routes, at least not publically so.

Freelance journalist Claudia Dalby covered a number of issues in more depth for IrishCycle.com this year: Why won’t councillors let slip lanes slip away; what’s next for the planned Rathmines bus gate; and is it possible to roll out quick-build cycle paths that are more pleasing to the eye.

An “accident waiting to happen” that happened

Councillors were seeking traffic calming what they called the “Mondello-like” Crumlin Road in Dublin but at a meeting back in July officials reminded them it’s an “arterial route”.

Then in November, Rosilaine Ribeiro, a 36-year-old Brazilian who was living in Dublin and working as a carer, was killed in a collision between her bicycle and a truck. The collision happened at the city centre end of the Crumlin Road on the bridge crossing the Grand Canal. Councillors linked the lack of action and the death of the woman.

Besides safety, another barrier to cycling is actual barriers on routes. While guidelines say restrictive barriers should not be used on cycle routes, restrictive barriers are still being installed which hinder or fully block routes for bicycles, including blocking children’s route to school due to “anti-social behaviour”. While, soon after, this site reported how the sod was turned on Royal Canal Greenway between Phibsborough and North Strand Road which will remove barriers to cycling along the route. It seems to be a cycle of up and downs in terms of progress on cycling.

Then there’s repeated silliness such as telling cyclists to pointlessly dismount beside €215 million upgrade to Cork motorway junction. While staggered barriers installed on the upgraded Galway city centre canal route are causing conflicts according to users of that route.

Dave Corley covered the issue from a Galway perspective in a comment article and asked: Can you imagine the uproar if car drivers had to navigate similar obstacles?

Bicycle parking where there’s no access to sheds

Bicycle parking for people who do not have easy access to a rear yard or shed was also a recurring issue — early in the year Waterford City looked to provide bicycle for residents on public streets using bike bunkers. Then in June, this website reported how An Bord Pleanála went against its inspector and rejected a bicycle bunker in a Clontarf front garden.

The Department of Housing said in July that it is “exploring” a planning exemption for bicycle storage at the front of houses. But, in the meantime, Cork City Council in September rejected a bicycle shed in the front driveway. But, in September, despite strong demand from residents and support from councillors, consultants recommend outsourcing Bike Bunker and reducing the target by 100 bicycle lockers.

Access to bicycles themselves can be a barrier especially when people are not sure about buying more expensive electric or cargo bikes — Budget 2024 didn’t bring any progress on grants for bicycles but there’s some good results from try-before-you-buy cargo bike schemes.

70% of participants in a scheme run by Limerick Cycling Campain said they are buying a bike, and a business-focused scheme run by Dublin City Council found that 90% of business participants indicated that they could see a use for cargo bikes in their business and 40% of participants have already taken the leap to integrate cargo bike use in their businesses.

And in other news…

Some of the non-cycling stories covered by IrishCycle.com which maybe didn’t get the attention they deserved included how Dublin Council said that a car park cannot be used for housing as it’s too close to train line, and how Irish Rail’s chairperson hit out at bureaucracy delaying approval of rail projects and new trains.
• Bicycle industry shot itself — and others — in the foot with 45km/h electric “bicycles” (46,311)
• Work stalled on busy Dublin cycle route as construction firm goes into liquidation (39,411)
• It looks grand, so, why won’t some cyclists use this cycling infrastructure? (25,970)
• Threatening cyclist with prosecution after reporting motorist’s close pass is part of policing “strategy”, says law lecturer (25,215)
• “As 1950s 12-year-olds, we cycled from Dalkey den to Powerscourt to camp… That’s a measure of how much we have lost of active childhood since” (19,814)
• Plan for 47 tables and 94 chairs for dining on busy Dublin footpath “madness” (17,826)
• Greenway bridge dropped in place between Phibsborough and Drumcondra (14,298)
• New bicycle taxi service to start in Dublin City Centre this Thursday (13,496)
• An Bord Pleanála goes against its inspector, rejects bicycle bunker in Clontarf front garden (12,619)
• Dublin City Council says car park cannot be used for housing as it’s too close to train line (12,380)
• “Hot topic” of ‘Living Streets’ Dún Laoghaire will see pedestrianisation of George’s Street, modal filters and renewal of Clarinda Park (11,983)

Number of updates per day in 2023
summary: The IrishCycle highlighted the slow progress and poor quality routes in the year leading up to record heat and warnings of climate change in Europe. The EPA warned that targeted emission reduction in transport will fall short, with transport being identified as one of the worst sectors. Transport Minister Eamon Ryan had encouraged councils to progress Pathfinder Projects, which have been delayed or low quality. The Department of Transport's research found that 60% of respondents were willing to change their transport choices to reduce carbon emissions, but campaigners questioned the availability of alternatives. Planning continued for Dublin’s MetroLink project, where stations are expected to have only 28% of the predicted demand of bicycle parking. Despite some progress in Cork on the reallocation of space to cycling, the multi-million euro revamp of MacCurtain St is still being treated as a car park. The Court of Appeal Justices highlighted the lack of Government guidelines covering the 38th Section of the 38-hour Road Traffic Act, which was last amended by the Public Transportation Act 2009.

title: Ring in the New Year with fireworks at Navy Pier and along the Chicago River downtown
description: The Merchandise Mart also will be lit up with the 5th annual ART on THE MART show for New Year's Eve.
content:
CHICAGO (CBS) -- The city of Chicago is ready to ring in 2024 with many events planned for New Year's Eve night, and fireworks set to go off at Navy Pier and along the riverfront.

The Aon Grand Ballroom at Navy Pier will host the Big Night Chicago New Year's Eve Gala, featuring drinks, dinner, dancing and more. The ballroom has been decked out, with multiple bars serving up the best VIP cuisine.

It's just one of multiple events happening here at Navy Pier, the hottest ticket in town for New Year's Eve.

"Offshore has an amazing gala that they're going to take place," Navy Pier spokeswoman Felicia Bolton said. "Bar Sol has a wonderful party, and then, of course, Odyssey on the boats. It's going to be absolutely phenomenal."

It all comes to a head when the clock strikes midnight -- with Navy Pier's annual award-winning fireworks show over Lake Michigan, featuring 100,000 pyrotechnics. The show is expected to last 10 minutes.

"The firework display is just so astonishing to see, and so it's just a beautiful way to say happy new year to everyone," Bolton said. "You can watch it from anywhere along Navy Pier."

At the same time as the Navy Pier fireworks show, the city will put on a fireworks display from six bridges along the Chicago River. Bridge closures will be in place at Franklin Street, LaSalle Street, Clark Street, Dearborn Street, State Street and Columbus Drive from 11:45 p.m. until 12:15 a.m. The Wabash and Michigan Avenue bridges will remain open.

Before the big fireworks display, celebrations will include a new program of the "Bes of the ART on THE MART," beginning at 7:30 p.m. on Dec. 31. The show will feature highlights of five years of ART on THE MART programming, culminating with the fireworks show along the river at midnight. The Riverwalk fireworks display will coincide with the Navy Pier fireworks show on the lakefront.

The ART on THE MART show will include projections by the following renowned artists and performers:
• Jan Tichy | Artes in Horto – Seven Gardens for Chicago

The Riverwalk will be closed beginning at 11 p.m., with only a section from Wells Street to Orleans Street open until 12:15 a.m. for spectators to enjoy the full audio/visual projection program for the ART on THE MART show and the riverfront fireworks.

entities.data: the "Bes of the ART on THE MART

summary: The city of Chicago is preparing for New Year's Eve with numerous events, including fireworks at Navy Pier and along the Chicago River downtown. The Aon Grand Ballroom at the Navy Pier will host a gala, featuring drinks, dinner, dancing, and more. The annual award-winning fireworks show over Lake Michigan will feature 100,000 pyrotechnics. The city will also put on a fireworks display from six bridges along the river at the same time. The Riverwalk will be closed beginning at 11 p.m., with only a section from Wells Street to Orleans Street remaining open until 12:15 a.m.

title: How a British comedy turned from a German New Year TV tradition to an online trend
description: YouTuber Ryan Wass reacts to the cult comedy short 'Dinner for One' in his video. 'Dinner for One' is a black-and-white comedy of manners about a Brit
content: BERLIN: "OK, the butler's setting the table", YouTuber Ryan Wass begins, sceptically. In his video "American Reacts to ' Dinner for One ', which he uploaded 11 months ago and now has 180,000 views, Wass takes a look at the cult comedy short. On his channel "Ryan Reaction", Wass regularly films himself being introduced to German idioms, customs,old films and TV shows from the perspective of an unwitting American viewer.But "Dinner for One" is no ordinary slice of quirky German culture.The 18-minute, black-and-white comedy of manners, filmed in 1963, is about a quintessentially British butler orchestrating a solo birthday celebration for his 90-year-old employer, whose closest friends and customary guests have all long since passed away. The butler, James, is obliged to fill in for the missing attendees, including quaffing each of their drinks. It's very British in style, and, apart from a brief German introduction, the action plays out in English."I have more questions than I did before it started," Wass says as the screening comes to an end. "Like, how is this a German tradition ?" "Dinner for One" debuted on the British stage in the 1930s. German entertainer Peter Frankenfeld saw it in the early 1960s while looking for material that might resonate with a German audience, and organised a live taping in Hamburg. After airing sporadically over the next several years, the film lucked into being a fixture of New Year's Eve TV programming in the 70s. Over the decades, the tradition has spread: It also plays annually in Sweden, Denmark, Austria and elsewhere. In Germany, "Dinner for One" screens on the TV channels of the country's many public broadcasters, sometimes several times a day on Dec. 31. Merchandise clogs German supermarkets: "Dinner for One" tea towels, puzzles and even an elaborate board game. Its ubiquity is unrelenting. If you own a TV in the country, you really can't miss it. Now, a generation of cord-cutters has also discovered the charms of this comedy, sharing and critiquing it online.All over YouTube, "Dinner for One" reaction videos have become popular, racking up tens of thousands of views. TikTokers aren't just sharing clips from the film. They're also staging their own intricate parodies, making lighthearted spoofs that riff on the familiar format. Clearly, a younger audience wants to keep the joke going - whether that means turning it to an annual viewing party or imagining what "Dinner for One" may look like if it were made by Quentin Tarantino.
summary: YouTuber Ryan Wass has turned "Dinner for One" a German New Year TV tradition into an online trend. The 18-minute black-and-white comedy was originally filmed in 1963 and is about a British butler performing a solo birthday celebration for his 90-year-old employer, whose friends and family have all died. The film, which debuted on the British stage in the 1930s, has since spread to other countries, including Sweden, Denmark, Austria and Germany. In Germany, it airs on the TV channels of many public broadcasters several times a day on New Year's Eve. However, a generation of cord-cutters have discovered the charm of this comedy, sharing and critiquing it online.

title: WWE Raw GM Adam Pearce Shares 2024 Announcement
description: WWE Raw GM Adam Pearce has shared a special 2024 announcement as a 'wild ride' of a year is coming to a close.
content:
WWE Raw GM Adam Pearce has shared a special 2024 announcement as a ‘wild ride’ of a year is coming to a close.

Sharing a video to his YouTube channel, Adam Pearce sat with a serious tone while he shared a message that he said was an announcement for 2024.

However, keen observers quickly took note that Pearce wasn’t actually saying a heartfelt announcement and was rather, repeating the lyrics to the classic 1987 Rick Astley hit, ‘Never Gonna Give You Up’.

Hilarious! You can see the entire troll below.

Elsewhere set to make history, WWE’s inaugural ‘New Year’s Knock Out Week’ kicking off with a big Day 1 edition of WWE Raw on Monday.

Already announced for the show, four matches that include both the top Men’s and Women’s championships on the line on the first day of 2024.

Seth Rollins looks to defend his WWE Heavyweight Championship against Drew McIntyre at Day 1.

Also, Rhea Ripley will look to keep her WWE Women’s Championship when she takes on Ivy Nile.

Additionally, set to tangle in the ring for the first time, a match five years in the making.

Becky Lynch will finally get to seek revenge against Nia Jax for breaking her nose all those years ago as the pair finally blow off their longstanding feud.

While not announced, Triple H indirectly responded to ‘rumors’ of a potential returning champion arriving as early as Day 1 to WWE simply for fans to tune in.

Tune in we shall Triple H, with a big week of programming set from WWE to kick off 2024 with a bang.

NXT’s special New Years Evil branded edition on Tuesday, two new offerings on Peacock for the week have also been announced.

With Wednesday set to premiere the Best of the Bump for 2023 as well as Best of Premium Live Events for 2023 on Thursday.

Thursday is also set to be the debut of a ‘WWE 2024 preview special’ and then Friday’s edition of SmackDown wrapping up the week with a special episode dubbed ‘New Year’s Revolution’.

You can keep up with all the latest news from around WWE by clicking this link.

Want to stay up to date with all the most important Wrestling and WrestleTalk News? Join our newsletter mailing list by clicking here, and selecting your preferences!

keywords.name: NXT’s special New Years Evil branded edition

summary: WWE Raw GM Adam Pearce has shared a special announcement for 2024, with a video of him repeating the lyrics to the 1987 Rick Astley song 'Never Gonna Give You Up' in which he claimed was an announcement for the year 2024. The announcement was made via a video posted on his YouTube channel, but it was later revealed that Pearce was actually repeating the song 'never Gonna Gonna Get You Up'. Other notable events include the first time seeing women's and men's championships on the line on the first day of the year, with Seth Rollins defending his WWE Heavyweight Championship against Drew McIntyre and Rhea Ripley defending her Women’s Championship against Ivy Nile. Additionally, WWE's inaugural 'New Year's Knock Out Week' will kick off with a big Day 1 edition of WWE Raw on Monday, with four matches already announced for the show.

title: Tourism is mixed blessing for Lahaina community still recovering from deadly wildfires
description: It's been four months since deadly wildfires ripped through the Maui community of Lahaina. Those who are rebuilding say they need tourists but, in a way, those
content:
It's been four months since deadly wildfires ripped through the Maui community of Lahaina. Those who are rebuilding say they need tourists but, in a way, those happy trips are also adding to their trauma.

The restaurant where Katie Austin worked was one of many that burned down. She tried to work at a different location, but the questions from travelers wore her down.

Was she affected by the wildfires? Did she lose anyone she loved?

"Everything has been taken over by tourism and we are put as second-class citizens, which people have felt for years," Austin said.

Hawaii's governor invited tourists back to the west side of Maui months after the August fire killed at least 100 people and destroyed more than 2,000 buildings.

PHOTOS FROM AUGUST: Fast-moving Hawaii fires will take a heavy toll on the state's environment



The area depends heavily on tourism, especially during the holidays. According to state data, tourism is down 20-30% for December.

"I don't think it's going to be very, very good. It's not good for our mental health when we see families frolicking around having a wonderful time while the whole community is suffering," said Austin.

Tensions are high over the lack of long-term, affordable housing for wildfire evacuees in Maui's tight and expensive market.

Dozens of people are still camping on the beach.

"We are using our native Hawaiian rights to hunt fish and gather to stay overnight," said Jordan Ruidas, who lives in Lahaina.

Hotels are still housing about 6,000 fire evacuees. Some have started to bring back tourists. Timeshare condo owners are also returning.

Restaurants and malls are busy, but many people are being reminded that supporting locals means more than just business.
summary: Four months after deadly wildfires destroyed the Maui community of Lahaina, killing at least 100 people and destroying over 2,000 buildings, has been a mixed blessing for the community still recovering from the devastating inferno. The tourism industry, which relies heavily on tourism, has seen a decrease in tourism, particularly during the holidays, with tourism down 20-30% for December. The restaurant where Katie Austin worked was one of many buildings that burned down, but she felt the tourism was taking over and putting her job at a different location. There are concerns over the lack of long-term, affordable housing for wildfire evacuees in Maui's tight and expensive market. Hotel rooms are housing about 6,000 evacuated people and some businesses are beginning to reopen, with many reminding locals that supporting locals is more than just business.

title: Houthi Militants Attack Container Ship, Maersk Halts Red Sea Sailing
description: The militants have been targeting vessels in the Red Sea since November to show their support for Palestinian Islamist group Hamas fighting Israel in Gaza.
content:
Iranian-backed Houthi militants attacked a Maersk container vessel with missiles and small boats, prompting the company to pause all sailing through the Red Sea for 48 hours, Maersk said on Sunday.

The crew of the Maersk Hangzhou crew was safe and there was no indication of fire onboard the vessel, which continued its journey north to Port Suez, the shipping company said.

A spokesman for the Houthis said the group carried out the attack because the ship’s crew refused to heed warning calls. He said 10 Houthi naval personnel were “dead and missing” after their boats were attacked by U.S. forces in the Red Sea.

White House national security spokesperson John Kirby declined to say what options are on or off the table when asked on ABC’s “Good Morning America” if Washington would consider a preemptive strike.

“We have made it clear publicly to the Houthis, we’ve made it clear privately to our allies and partners in the region, that we take these threats seriously.”

The attack on Maersk Hangzhou was the latest by Houthi militants in Yemen, who have been targeting vessels in the Red Sea since November to show their support for Palestinian Islamist group Hamas fighting Israel in Gaza.

The attacks have disrupted world trade, with major shipping companies taking the longer and costlier route around the Africa’s Cape of Good Hope rather than through the Suez Canal.

The Red Sea is the entry point for ships using the Suez Canal, which handles about 12% of global trade and vital for the movement of goods between Asia and Europe.

The United States launched Operation Prosperity Guardian on Dec. 19, saying more than 20 countries had agreed to participate in the efforts to safeguard ships in Red Sea waters near Yemen.

In response, Maersk said on Dec. 24 it would resume sailing through the Red Sea. However, attacks have continued and U.S. allies have proven reluctant to commit to the coalition, with nearly half not declaring their presence publicly.

On Sunday, Maersk, one of the world’s major cargo shippers, said it would delay all transits through the area for 48 hours, after the Maersk Hangzhou was struck by a missile at around 1730 GMT on Saturday 55 nautical miles southwest of Al Hodeidah, Yemen.

A U.S. warship shot down another two anti-ship ballistic missiles fired at the ship, CENTCOM said.

Efforts to ward off the four boats at around 0330 GMT on Sunday as the attackers sought to board the vessel involved the ship’s security team as well as helicopters from the USS Eisenhower and USS Gravely, Maersk and CENTCOM said.

The Singapore-flagged Maersk Hangzhou with capacity to carry 14,000 containers was en route from Singapore.

British Foreign Secretary David Cameron said on Sunday that he had told Iranian Foreign Minister Hossein Amirabdollahian in a call that Iran should help stop the Houthi attacks in the Red Sea.

“I made clear that Iran shares responsibility for preventing these attacks, given their long-standing support to the Houthis,” Cameron said in a post on social media site X, adding that the attacks “threaten innocent lives and the global economy”.

The BIMCO shipping association condemned the attacks and thanked those states involved in repelling them.

“We are thankful to U.S., French, and UK efforts so far and hope even more states will support the coalition with naval assets or other impactful means including diplomatic pressure on the Houthis and their sponsors,” Jakob Larsen, BIMCO’s head of maritime safety and security, told Reuters.
summary: Iranian-backed Houthi militants have attacked a Maersk container vessel with missiles and small boats, leading to the company to suspend all sailing through the Red Sea for 48 hours. The crew of the Maersh Hangzhou crew was safe and there was no indication of fire onboard the vessel. The Houthis claimed the attack was carried out because the ship's crew refused to heed warning calls. This is the latest by Houthi militant in Yemen who have been targeting vessels in the red Sea since November to support Hamas in Gaza. The attacks have disrupted global trade, leading major shipping companies to take the longer and costlier route around the Africa’s Cape of Good Hope rather than the Suez Canal. The United States launched Operation Prosperity Guardian on Dec. 19 to protect ships in Red Sea waters near Yemen but attacks have continued.

authors_byline: NIDAL AL-MUGHRABI, DAN WILLIAMS, ARAFAT BARBAKH, Reuters
title: Israel pounds Gaza, Hamas fires rockets as Netanyahu indicates long war
description: Israeli jets intensified attacks on central Gaza on Sunday, residents and medics said, as battles raged through the rubble of towns and refugee camps in a war Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said would take "many more months" to end.
content:
Israeli soldiers operate in the Gaza Strip amid the ongoing conflict between Israel and the Palestinian Islamist group Hamas, in this handout picture released December 30, 2023. Israel Defense Forces/Handout via REUTERS

CAIRO/GAZA/JERUSALEM - Israeli jets intensified attacks on central Gaza on Sunday, residents and medics said, as battles raged through the rubble of towns and refugee camps in a war Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said would take "many more months" to end.

Netanyahu's comments signal no let-up in a campaign that has killed many thousands and levelled much of Gaza, while his vow to restore Israeli control over the enclave's border with Egypt raises new questions over an eventual two-state solution.

The Israeli military will release some reservists who were called up to fight Hamas in Gaza, a move it said on Sunday would help the economy as the country prepares for a prolonged war.

Air strikes pounded al-Maghazi and al-Bureij in the center of Gaza, killing 10 people in one house and driving more to flee to Rafah on the border with Egypt from front lines where Israeli tanks are battling Hamas fighters.

Rockets fired from Gaza raced toward central Israel overnight, triggering sirens throughout the central and southern parts of the country. Israeli media carried footage of numerous interceptions. There were no reports of any direct hits.

Hamas' armed wing said the barrage was in response to "massacres against civilians" in Gaza.

A Red Crescent video published on Sunday showed rescuers working in the dark to carry an injured child from smoking rubble in central Gaza. Six people died in a strike on the village of al-Mughraqa outside Gaza City, health officials said. A separate strike on a house in Khan Younis killed one person and wounded others, they added.

As 2023 drew to a close, Palestinians in Gaza prayed for a ceasefire but had little hope the new year would be better.

“Tonight the sky in world countries will be lit by firecrackers, and joyful laughs will fill the air. In Gaza our skies are now filled with Israeli missiles and tank shells that land on innocent, homeless civilians,” said Zainab Khalil, 57, a resident from northern Gaza now in Rafah.

The stated goal of Israel's military is to eliminate Hamas, the Palestinian militant group that launched a surprise cross-border assault on Israeli towns on Oct. 7, killing 1,200 people, mostly civilians, and grabbing 240 hostages.

Israel's air and artillery bombardment has killed more than 21,800 people according to health authorities in Hamas-run Gaza, with many more feared dead in the rubble, and pushed nearly all of its 2.3 million people from their homes.

Palestinian health ministry casualty figures do not differentiate between fighters and civilians but the ministry has said that 70% of Gaza's dead are women and people under 18. Israel disputes Palestinian casualty figures and says it has killed 8,000 fighters.

Israel blockaded most food, fuel and medicine after the Oct. 7 attack. It said on Sunday that it was ready to let ships from some Western countries deliver aid directly to Gaza's shores after security checks in Cyprus.

Gemma Connell, an official with the UN humanitarian agency OCHA, said that many of the tens of thousands of people fleeing to Rafah had no possessions and nowhere to sleep.

"I just am so fearful that the amount of deaths that we've been seeing is going to increase exponentially both because of this renewed offensive but also because of these conditions which are literally unbelievable," she said.

'Where will people go?'

The United States, Israel's main ally, has urged it to scale down the war and European states have signaled alarm at the extent of Palestinian civilian suffering.

However Netanyahu's comments on Saturday, when he said he would not resign despite opinion polls showing his government is broadly unpopular and defended his security record despite the Oct. 7 attack, indicate that there will be no easing anytime soon.

Netanyahu said the "the war is at its height" and Israel would have to retake control of Gaza's border with Egypt, an area now crammed with civilians who have fled the carnage across the rest of the enclave.

Retaking the border could also constitute a de facto reversal of Israel's 2005 withdrawal from Gaza, raising new questions over the future of the enclave and prospects for a Palestinian state.

Washington said Israel should allow a Palestinian government to control Gaza when the conflict is over.

"We just take a fundamentally different view here in terms of what post-conflict Gaza needs to look like," White House national security spokesperson John Kirby said on ABC television.

Israel's hard-right Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich fueled concerns about the offensive's aims on Sunday by calling for Palestinians to leave Gaza and make way for Israelis who could "make the desert bloom."

That clashed with the official Israeli government position that Gazans will be able to return to their homes. Smotrich and other hardline coalition ministers have been excluded from the core war cabinet but have pushed to take part in decisions about the conflict.

In his last comments as Israeli foreign minister before switching to the energy portfolio on Sunday, Eli Cohen said the border was the likely source of weaponry Hamas had obtained over recent years.

Senior Palestinian Authority official Hussein al-Sheikh in the Israeli-occupied West Bank said via social media that Israel taking over the border was evidence of a decision "to completely return the occupation."

"We moved here from Khan Younis on the basis that Rafah was a safe place. There is no space in Rafah as it is overcrowded with displaced," said Umm Mohammed, 45, a displaced Palestinian woman sheltering by the border.

"If they control the border, where will people go?" she asked, saying that would be "a disaster."

The war risks morphing into a wider regional conflict involving Hamas ally Iran and groups Tehran supports across the Middle East.

Israel and Lebanon's Iran-backed Hezbollah have exchanged regular cross-border fire, with the Israeli military saying it struck targets in Lebanon on Sunday. Israel has hit Iran-linked targets in Syria. And Iran-backed groups have attacked US targets in Iraq.

Yemen's Iran-aligned Houthi group, which has been attacking shipping in the Red Sea for weeks in what it calls a response to Israel's war in Gaza, attacked a Maersk cargo ship, the US military said.

US naval helicopters sank three of the four small boats the Houthis had used in Sunday's attack and drove the fourth back to shore, the military said.

Israel says 174 of its military personnel have been killed in the Gaza fighting but that its operations are making progress, including by destroying some Hamas tunnels under the enclave.

Hamas and Islamic Jihad — both sworn to Israel's destruction — have said that they continue to target Israeli forces operating in the enclave. —Reuters
summary: Israeli jets intensified their attacks on central Gaza on Sunday, killing 10 people and driving more people to Rafah on the border with Egypt from front lines where Israeli tanks are battling Hamas fighters. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu stated that the war would take "many more months" to end. His comments indicate no let-up in the campaign that has killed many thousands and destroyed much of Gaza. The Israeli military plans to release some reservists who have been called up to fight Hamas in Gaza, a move it says will aid the economy. The conflict has left over 21,800 people dead and displaced nearly all of Gaza's 2.3 million people from their homes. The United States, Israel's main ally, has urged Israel to scale down the war and European states have expressed concern over the extent of Palestinian civilian suffering.

title: Η Ελλάδα καλωσορίζει το 2024 με γιορτές, συναυλίες, πάρτι και σόου πυροτεχνημάτων
description: Από άκρη σε άκρη η Ελλάδα ετοιμάζεται να υποδεχτεί το 2024 με εορταστικές εκδηλώσεις  που έχουν προγραμματιστεί στα κέντρα μεγάλων και μικρότερων πόλεων της χώρας, με τις εκδηλώσεις στην Αθήνα και τη Θεσσαλονίκη να βρίσκονται στο επίκεντρο
content:
Η πρωτοχρονιάτικη γιορτή της Πλατείας Συντάγματος ξεκίνησε στις 22:00 με χριστουγεννιάτικες μελωδίες από τη Φιλαρμονική Ορχήστρα του Δήμου Αθηναίων, και οικοδεσπότες την Νάνσυ Ζαμπέτογλου και τον Θανάση Αναγνωστόπουλο που θα υποδεχθούν στη σκηνή τον νέο Δήμαρχο Αθηναίων Χάρη Δούκα, ο οποίος λίγα δευτερόλεπτα πριν τα μεσάνυχτα θα δώσει το σύνθημα για την παραδοσιακή αντίστροφη μέτρηση της αλλαγής του χρόνου. Στην αλλαγή του χρόνου πυροτεχνήματα θα φωτίσουν τον αττικό ουρανό καλωσορίζοντας με λάμψη το 2024.

Ο Νίκος Πορτοκάλογλου θα ανέβει στη σκηνή με την Βίκυ Καρατζόγλου, μία από τις νεότερες αναγνωρίσιμες γνήσιες λαϊκές φωνές, τον Βύρωνα Τσουράπη, πιστό συνοδοιπόρο του στις ζωντανές εμφανίσεις του, αλλά και τη δυναμική μπάντα «Ευγενείς Αλήτες» με τους Θανάση Τσακιράκη, Ηλία Λαμπρόπουλο, Αλέξανδρο Ζουγανέλη και Κατερίνα Λιάκη.

Το δικό της στίγμα θα δώσει στη βραδιά και η δημοφιλής τραγουδίστρια και εκπρόσωπος της Ελλάδας στη Eurovision 2024, Μαρίνα Σάττι, με τους pop, mainstream και ethnic ρυθμούς της ως τις πρώτες ώρες του 2024.

Πάρτι ως το πρωί στη Βαρβάκειο!

Παράλληλα, από τις 23:00, και αυτήν την Πρωτοχρονιά η Βαρβάκειος Αγορά μετατρέπεται στο απόλυτο πρωτοχρονιάτικο dance floor! Ο Δήμος Αθηναίων και οι Street Outdoors μας προσκαλούν στο μεγαλύτερο και πιο ιδιαίτερο ΝΥΕ party της πόλης, όπου καταξιωμένοι DJ και παραγωγοί αναλαμβάνουν τα decks και μοιράζουν upbeat μουσική για χορό ως το πρωί.

Στη Θεσσαλονίκη η οποία κινείται σε ιδιαίτερους ρυθμούς από το πρωί της Κυριακής, ο ουρανός αναμένεται να γεμίσει με φαναράκια, με πρωτοβουλία του Εμπορικού Συλλόγου.

Μουσικά shows, χριστουγεννιάτικα happenings καθώς και άλλες δρατηριότητες σε γιορτινό κλίμα λαμβάνουν χώρα από το απόγευμα.

Τον ουρανό της Θεσσαλονίκης αναμένεται να φωτίσουν εντυπωσιακά πυροτεχνήματα στην αλλαγή του χρόνου. Η ρίψη τους θα γίνει στην πλατεία Αριστοτέλους. Πρόκειται για το «Fanarakia Christmas Event», που διοργάνωσε για δεύτερη συνεχόμενη χρονιά ο Εμπορικός Σύλλογος Θεσσαλονίκης.

Χανιά: Χαμός από κόσμο στο κέντρο για την αλλαγή του χρόνου

Πλήθος κόσμου στους δρόμους των Χανίων την τελευταία ημέρα του 2023. Οι Χανιώτες επέλεξαν να κατεβούν στην πόλη για ψώνια, φαγητό, ή και απλά για μια βόλτα και στο κέντρο της πόλης δημιουργήθηκε το αδιαχώρητο.
translation:
The New Year's celebration of Syntagma Square started at 10:00 p.m. with Christmas tunes by the Philharmonic Orchestra of the Municipality of Athens, and hosts Nancy Zampetoglou and Thanasis Anagnostopoulos who will welcome on stage the new Mayor of Athens Haris Doukas, who a few seconds before midnight will give the cue for the traditional time change countdown. At the change of time, fireworks will light up the Attic sky, welcoming 2024 with brilliance.

Nikos Portokaloglou will take the stage with Vicky Karatzoglou, one of the youngest recognizable genuine popular voices, Byron Tsourapis, his loyal companion in his live performances, and the dynamic band "Gentle Tramps" with Thanasis Tsakirakis, Ilias Lambropoulos, Alexandros Zouganelis and Katerina Liaki.

The popular singer and representative of Greece in Eurovision 2024, Marina Satti, will give her own stamp to the evening, with her pop, mainstream and ethnic rhythms until the early hours of 2024.

Party until the morning in Varvakeio!

At the same time, from 23:00, this New Year's Eve, Varvakeios Agora turns into the ultimate New Year's dance floor! The Municipality of Athens and Street Outdoors invite us to the biggest and most special NYE party in the city, where renowned DJs and producers take over the decks and distribute upbeat music for dancing until the morning.

In Thessaloniki, which has been moving at a special pace since Sunday morning, the sky is expected to be filled with lanterns, at the initiative of the Trade Association.

Music shows, Christmas happenings as well as other activities in a festive atmosphere take place from the afternoon.

Spectacular fireworks are expected to light up the sky of Thessaloniki at the change of season. They will be thrown in Aristotelous Square. This is the "Fanarakia Christmas Event", organized for the second consecutive year by the Thessaloniki Chamber of Commerce.

Chania: Destruction of people in the center for the change of time

Crowds of people on the streets of Chania on the last day of 2023. The people of Chania chose to go down to the city for shopping, eating, or even just for a walk and in the center of the city the indivisible was created.
translated_title: Greece welcomes 2024 with celebrations, concerts, parties and fireworks
translated_description: From end to end Greece is gearing up to welcome 2024 with festive events planned in the country's city centers large and small, with events in Athens and Thessaloniki taking center stage
translated_summary: The Greek New Year's Eve celebrations were held in Syntagma Square, with the Philharmonic Orchestra of Athens, hosts Nancy Zampetoglou and Thanasis Anagnostopoulos, and the new Mayor of Athens Haris Doukas. The celebration began at 10:00 p.m. with Christmas tunes by the Philharmonic Orchestra and hosted by the Municipality of Athens. Other performances included Nikos Portokaloglou, Vicky Karatzoglou, Byron Tsourapis, and a band "Gentle Tramps". The popular singer and representative of Greece in Eurovision 2024, Marina Satti, will give her own stamp to the evening, with her pop, mainstream and ethnic rhythms until the early hours of 2024. From 23:00, Varvakeios Agora will host the biggest and most special NYE party in Athens, where renowned DJs and producers distribute upbeat music for dancing until the morning. Spectacular fireworks are expected to light up the sky of Thessaloniki at the change of season, with spectacular fireworks being thrown in Aristotelous Square. In Thessaloiki, the city will also be filled with lanterns and music shows, Christmas happenings, and other activities throughout the day.

title: Golf course rewilding
description: How to make your golf course nature friendly
content:
Golf courses are renowned for their flawless green expanses, manicured fairways, and pristine landscapes. However, these carefully maintained spaces offer limited biodiversity and ecological benefits. This article explores how to transform British golf courses into wildlife havens while ensuring they remain enjoyable for golfers.

Before embarking on the journey of rewilding a golf course, it is essential to assess the existing environment. Study the layout, identify areas with high ecological value, and zones that can be redesigned or adapted for supporting wildlife. Collaborating with ecologists, landscape architects, and golfing experts can provide valuable insight and guidance in the process.

The first step towards a wildlife-friendly golf course is to establish a variety of ecological zones. Dedicate areas to different wildlife habitats such as meadows, wetlands, woodland edges, and ponds. This can be achieved by reducing the area of mowed turf and allowing indigenous plants to flourish, promoting natural vegetation growth.

Introducing native plant species is key to enhancing biodiversity on a golf course. Replace non-native exotic plants with native wildflowers, grasses, shrubs, and trees, as these provide essential food sources, nesting opportunities, and shelter for various wildlife species. Focus on selecting species that attract pollinators, like bees and butterflies, as they contribute to the health and fertility of the ecosystem.

Water is essential for all forms of life, and golf courses often have large areas dedicated to lakes and ponds. Optimize these water bodies to support diverse wildlife habitats. Create shallow margins around ponds and lakes with native aquatic plants, attracting amphibians, dragonflies, ducks, and other water-dependent species.

When managing a rewilded golf course, it is crucial to implement wildlife-friendly practices. Avoid the excessive use of pesticides and herbicides, which can harm wildlife and disrupt ecological balance. Encourage the return of natural predators like owls, bats, and birds of prey to control pest populations, offering balanced ecological control without resorting to chemicals.

One of the critical aspects of a rewilding endeavour is involving golfers and visitors in appreciating and participating in this transformation. Provide educational materials, signage, and guided tours, highlighting the importance of biodiversity, conservation efforts, and the interdependence of ecological systems. Encourage golfers to get involved and contribute positively to the ecosystem's health during their rounds.

While rewilding is focused on promoting biodiversity, it is equally important to maintain the golf course's playability and enjoyment for golfers. Striking a balance is crucial. Carve out areas as wildlife zones, while ensuring fairways, greens, and tee boxes remain well-maintained for optimal golfing conditions. The successful integration of these aspects will foster harmony between golfers and nature.

Rewilding a British golf course is an exceptional opportunity to embrace and encourage biodiversity. By thoughtfully incorporating ecological zones, native plant cultivation, strategic water management, and wildlife-friendly practices, golf courses can become thriving habitats for countless wildlife species. Simultaneously, educating golfers and visitors is vital in fostering a deeper appreciation for the interconnectedness of nature. Ultimately, a wildlife-friendly golf course combines the joys of golf with the beauty and benefits of nature, creating a win-win situation for all.
summary: Golf courses, often known for their pristine landscapes, offer limited biodiversity and ecological benefits. This article discusses how to transform British golf courses into wildlife havens while ensuring they remain enjoyable for golfers. The first step towards a wildlife-friendly golf course is to establish a variety of ecological zones, dedicate areas to different wildlife habitats, such as meadows, wetlands, woodland edges, and ponds. Introducing native plant species is a crucial step, with replacing non-native exotic plants with native wildflowers, grasses, shrubs, and trees as these provide essential food sources, nesting opportunities, and shelter for wildlife species. Management is essential to avoid the excessive use of pesticides and herbicides, which can harm wildlife and disrupt ecological balance. The successful integration of these aspects will foster harmony between golfers and nature.
